articles.headline: G.O.P. Rifts Lead Congress to Spending Impasse
articles.snippet: The collapse of spending measures increased the prospects of a government shutdown in the fall and added new urgency to fiscal negotiations between the White House and a bloc of Senate Republicans.
articles.abstract: The collapse of spending measures increased the prospects of a government shutdown in the fall and added new urgency to fiscal negotiations between the White House and a bloc of Senate Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours before leaving on summer recess, Congress on Thursday hit a seemingly intractable impasse on government spending, increasing the prospects of a government shutdown in the fall and adding new urgency to fiscal negotiations between the White House and a bloc of Senate Republicans.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Barclays, Caught Short, Is Now in a Bind
articles.snippet: A British regulator finds that Barclays is seriously undercapitalized, and the bank doesn’t have much time to fix that.
articles.abstract: A British regulator finds that Barclays is seriously undercapitalized, and the bank doesn’t have much time to fix that.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We continue to believe that we’re well capitalized.”

articles.headline: With Moto X, Google Enters a Crowded Marketplace
articles.snippet: The search giant, which has stumbled in its forays into the hardware market, says its high-end Moto X smartphone has innovative voice controls.
articles.abstract: The search giant, which has stumbled in its forays into the hardware market, says its high-end Moto X smartphone has innovative voice controls.
articles.lead_paragraph: The time has come for Google, the king of online search, to show whether it has any business selling hardware.

articles.headline: Former Trader Is Found Liable in Fraud Case
articles.snippet: Fabrice Tourre, the former Goldman Sachs trader at the center of a toxic mortgage deal sold to investors on the eve of the financial crisis, was found liable on six of the seven civil charges against him.
articles.abstract: Fabrice Tourre, the former Goldman Sachs trader at the center of a toxic mortgage deal sold to investors on the eve of the financial crisis, was found liable on six of the seven civil charges against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:03 p.m. | A former Goldman Sachs trader at the center of a toxic mortgage deal lost a closely watched legal battle on Thursday, giving Wall Street’s top regulator its first significant courtroom victory in a case stemming from the financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Increase in Urine Testing Raises Ethical Questions
articles.snippet: The growth of tests for painkillers has led to concerns about their accuracy and whether some companies and doctors are exploiting them for profit.
articles.abstract: The growth of tests for painkillers has led to concerns about their accuracy and whether some companies and doctors are exploiting them for profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: As doctors try to ensure their patients do not abuse prescription drugs, they are relying more and more on sophisticated urine-screening tests to learn which drugs patients are taking and — just as important — which ones they’re not.

articles.headline: Theory on Pain Is Driving Rules for Abortions
articles.snippet: Measures that ban abortion 20 weeks after conception, on the disputed idea that the fetus can feel pain at that point, have spread by tapping into public concern about late-stage abortions.
articles.abstract: Measures that ban abortion 20 weeks after conception, on the disputed idea that the fetus can feel pain at that point, have spread by tapping into public concern about late-stage abortions.
articles.lead_paragraph: It challenges four decades of constitutional doctrine and is based on disputed scientific theories.

articles.headline: For Penney, Stewart Trial’s Outcome Is Just One Pressing Concern
articles.snippet: Management and financial turmoil has plagued J.C. Penney in recent months, unfolding along with a trial over whether the company could sell Martha Stewart’s goods.
articles.abstract: Management and financial turmoil has plagued J.C. Penney in recent months, unfolding along with a trial over whether the company could sell Martha Stewart’s goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: In February, when a trial over whether J. C. Penney could sell Martha Stewart’s goods began, Penney’s fortunes were teetering.

articles.headline: Hiring of Fired Trader Offers a Glimpse Into SAC’s Practices
articles.snippet: The former trader is said to tell authorities of other incidents of insider trading by the hedge fund run by Steven A. Cohen.
articles.abstract: The former trader is said to tell authorities of other incidents of insider trading by the hedge fund run by Steven A. Cohen.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard S. Lee’s first day of running a trading desk was his last.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Obama Narrows Field for Fed Chairman to 3
articles.snippet: President Obama is said to be choosing between Larry Summers, his former economic adviser; Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve’s vice chairwoman; and Donald L. Kohn, a former Fed vice chairman.
articles.abstract: President Obama is said to be choosing between Larry Summers, his former economic adviser; Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve’s vice chairwoman; and Donald L. Kohn, a former Fed vice chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This week, in a closed-door meeting of Congressional Democrats with President Obama, Representative Ed Perlmutter of Colorado bluntly said what has been on many politicians’ minds: “Larry Summers. Bad choice.”

articles.headline: Michael Dell Salvages Bid for His Company
articles.snippet: Under the terms of the new agreement, Michael S. Dell and his partner, the investment firm Silver Lake, would pay $13.75 a share plus a 13-cent special dividend. The latest compromise pushes a shareholder vote to September.
articles.abstract: Under the terms of the new agreement, Michael S. Dell and his partner, the investment firm Silver Lake, would pay $13.75 a share plus a 13-cent special dividend. The latest compromise pushes a shareholder vote to September.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Michael S. Dell’s takeover bid for the company he founded appeared to be in peril on Wednesday, he sprang into action to try to save it.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: U.S. Adds 162,000 Jobs as Growth Remains Sluggish
articles.snippet: The employment gains in July, which were fewer than expected, were not on track to absorb the backlog of unemployed workers anytime soon. The jobless rate ticked down to 7.4%.
articles.abstract: The employment gains in July, which were fewer than expected, were not on track to absorb the backlog of unemployed workers anytime soon. The jobless rate ticked down to 7.4%.
articles.lead_paragraph: The painfully long and slow recovery of the American economy stumbled last month as employers added a disappointing 162,000 jobs, the government reported on Friday, leaving uncertainty about the timing of the Federal Reserve’s plans to begin tapering its extraordinary efforts to revive healthy growth after the financial crisis that hit the world five years ago.

articles.headline: Court Rulings Blur the Line Between a Spy and a Leaker
articles.snippet: Disclosures made possible by digital media, government surveillance and unorthodox publishers have unsettled understandings of mass media’s place in American democracy.
articles.abstract: Disclosures made possible by digital media, government surveillance and unorthodox publishers have unsettled understandings of mass media’s place in American democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government is prosecuting leakers at a brisk clip and on novel theories. It is collecting information from and about journalists, calling one a criminal and threatening another with jail. In its failed effort to persuade Russia to return another leaker, Edward J. Snowden, it felt compelled to say that he would not be tortured or executed.
